The outline is intended to be low-stakes and is primarily designed to be a means for you to obtain feedback on the feasibility of the project and areas to consider. # Homework Review Homeworks 2 & 3 # Data Wrangling with `{dplyr}` Week 4 ## ![](https://www.ltd.org/files/library/bus-with-rainbow_lb.jpg) ## ![](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1572013343866-dfdb9b416810?ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8N3x8dGF4aXxlbnwwfHwwfHx8MA%3D%3D&auto=format&fit=crop&w=500&q=60) ## Agenda {.smaller} - Introduce common `{dplyr}` functions + piping `{dplyr}` functions + helper functions - Introduce complimentary functions + `ifelse()` + `case_when()` ![](https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2023/08/teach-tidyverse-23/#quality-of-life-improvements-to-case_when-and-if_else) **Learning Objectives** - Understand basic data wrangling and transformations + `select()` + `filter()` + `arrange()` + `group_by()` + `summarize()` + `recode()` & `rename()` - Be able to pipe these functions to efficiently wrangle data ## ![](https://cdn.myportfolio.com/45214904-6a61-4e23-98d6-b140f8654a40/b467ee99-87e3-4663-ae27-aaf027f940ce_rw_1920.png?h=0573cb8b960ba2f2c8486188761f03e0){width="70%"} ::: aside Credit [Allison Horst](https://allisonhorst.com/data-science-art) ::: ## Providing grammar for: * Graphics + `{ggplot2}` * Data manipulations + `{dplyr}` + `{tidyr}` * Expanding area of specialized topics + `{lubridate}` + `{glue}` + `{tidymodels}` * Many more... ## Providing grammar for: * Graphics + `{ggplot2}` * Data manipulations + `{dplyr}` + `{tidyr}` * Expanding area of specialized topics + `{lubridate}` + `{glue}` + `{tidymodels}` * Many more... # {dplyr} ## `{dplyr}` ![](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/621a9c8c5d7b47c4b6d72e8f01f28d14310e8370/193fc/css/images/hex/dplyr.png){fig-align="right" width="10%"} {.smaller} A grammar for data wrangling (verbs!) Take a couple minutes with your neighbor to guess what the following functions do: * `select()` * `filter()` * `mutate()` * `arrange()` * `summarize()` * `group_by()` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## `{dplyr}` {.smaller} A grammar for data wrangling (verbs!) `select()` ::: {.fragment} a subset of **columns** ::: `filter()` ::: {.fragment} a subset of **rows** ::: `mutate()` ::: {.fragment} **add** a new column or **modify** an existing column ::: `arrange()` ::: {.fragment} **sort** rows in ascending/descending order ::: `summarize()` ::: {.fragment} a new column created according to other columns for example: `mean()` or `sd()` + often used with... ::: `group_by()` ::: {.fragment} **grouping** column(s) ::: ## Arguments * **`{dplyr}` always takes a data frame (tibble) as the first argument** + just like `{ggplot}` * subsequent functions tell `{dplyr}` what to do with the data frame * each function applied returns the modified data frame # `select()` ## `select()` choose columns :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data.frame %>% select(a, c) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-gapminder/fig/13-dplyr-fig1.png) ::: :::: ::: aside Image from [Software Carpentry](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-gapminder/fig/13-dplyr-fig1.png) ::: ## Examples Let‚Äôs start with the presidential dataset from the `{mdsr}` package ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) #install.packages("mdsr") library(mdsr) presidential ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Eisenhower 1953-01-20 1961-01-20 Republican 2 Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 Democratic 3 Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 Democratic 4 Nixon 1969-01-20 1974-08-09 Republican 5 Ford 1974-08-09 1977-01-20 Republican 6 Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 Democratic 7 Reagan 1981-01-20 1989-01-20 Republican 8 Bush 1989-01-20 1993-01-20 Republican 9 Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 Democratic 10 Bush 2001-01-20 2009-01-20 Republican 11 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic 12 Trump 2017-01-20 2021-01-20 Republican ``` ::: ::: ## `select` president *name* and *party* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(presidential, name, party) ``` ::: . . . **OR** more typically ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(name, party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 2 name party 1 Eisenhower Republican 2 Kennedy Democratic 3 Johnson Democratic 4 Nixon Republican 5 Ford Republican 6 Carter Democratic 7 Reagan Republican 8 Bush Republican 9 Clinton Democratic 10 Bush Republican 11 Obama Democratic 12 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Negation `-` Don't select variable(s) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(-start) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 3 name end party 1 Eisenhower 1961-01-20 Republican 2 Kennedy 1963-11-22 Democratic 3 Johnson 1969-01-20 Democratic 4 Nixon 1974-08-09 Republican 5 Ford 1977-01-20 Republican 6 Carter 1981-01-20 Democratic 7 Reagan 1989-01-20 Republican 8 Bush 1993-01-20 Republican 9 Clinton 2001-01-20 Democratic 10 Bush 2009-01-20 Republican 11 Obama 2017-01-20 Democratic 12 Trump 2021-01-20 Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Negation `-` Don't select variable(s) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(-start, -end) ``` ::: **OR** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(-c(start, end)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 2 name party 1 Eisenhower Republican 2 Kennedy Democratic 3 Johnson Democratic 4 Nixon Republican 5 Ford Republican 6 Carter Democratic 7 Reagan Republican 8 Bush Republican 9 Clinton Democratic 10 Bush Republican 11 Obama Democratic 12 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Indexing Less preferable because variable orders change ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(presidential, 1:3) ``` ::: **OR** more typically ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(1:3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 3 name start end 1 Eisenhower 1953-01-20 1961-01-20 2 Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 3 Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 4 Nixon 1969-01-20 1974-08-09 5 Ford 1974-08-09 1977-01-20 6 Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 7 Reagan 1981-01-20 1989-01-20 8 Bush 1989-01-20 1993-01-20 9 Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 10 Bush 2001-01-20 2009-01-20 11 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 12 Trump 2017-01-20 2021-01-20 ``` ::: ::: ## Use multiple methods ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% select(name, 2, 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 3 name start party 1 Eisenhower 1953-01-20 Republican 2 Kennedy 1961-01-20 Democratic 3 Johnson 1963-11-22 Democratic 4 Nixon 1969-01-20 Republican 5 Ford 1974-08-09 Republican 6 Carter 1977-01-20 Democratic 7 Reagan 1981-01-20 Republican 8 Bush 1989-01-20 Republican 9 Clinton 1993-01-20 Democratic 10 Bush 2001-01-20 Republican 11 Obama 2009-01-20 Democratic 12 Trump 2017-01-20 Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Use `select` to order columns ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(fivethirtyeight) college_grad_students ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 173 √ó 22 major_code major major_category grad_total grad_sample_size grad_employed 1 5601 Construc‚Ä¶ Industrial Ar‚Ä¶ 9173 200 7098 2 6004 Commerci‚Ä¶ Arts 53864 882 40492 3 6211 Hospital‚Ä¶ Business 24417 437 18368 4 2201 Cosmetol‚Ä¶ Industrial Ar‚Ä¶ 5411 72 3590 5 2001 Communic‚Ä¶ Computers & M‚Ä¶ 9109 171 7512 6 3201 Court Re‚Ä¶ Law & Public ‚Ä¶ 1542 22 1008 7 6206 Marketin‚Ä¶ Business 190996 3738 151570 8 1101 Agricult‚Ä¶ Agriculture &‚Ä¶ 17488 386 13104 9 2101 Computer‚Ä¶ Computers & M‚Ä¶ 5611 98 4716 10 1904 Advertis‚Ä¶ Communication‚Ä¶ 33928 688 28517 # ‚Ñπ 163 more rows # ‚Ñπ 16 more variables: grad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # grad_unemployed , grad_unemployment_rate , grad_p25th , # grad_median , grad_p75th , nongrad_total , # nongrad_employed , nongrad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # nongrad_unemployed , nongrad_unemployment_rate , # nongrad_p25th , nongrad_median , nongrad_p75th , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## `select()` [helper](https://tidyselect.r-lib.org/reference/select_helpers.html) functions * `everything()` * `starts_with()` * `ends_with()` * `contains()` * `all_of()` * `any_of()` ## Helper functions First: this code may not work for you - why? ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} reads <- read_csv(here("data", "Project_Reads_Scores.csv")) %>% clean_names() reads ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 25 test_year test_type test_site student_id pre_test_score pre_test_percent 1 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 1 43 29% 2 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 2 46 31% 3 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 3 39 26% 4 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 4 35 23% 5 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 5 46 31% 6 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 6 35 23% 7 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 7 40 27% 8 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 8 39 26% 9 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 9 40 27% 10 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 10 45 30% # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows # ‚Ñπ 19 more variables: post_test_score , post_test_percent , # percentage_change , unit_1_score , unit_1_percent , # unit_2_score , unit_2_percent , unit_3_score , # unit_3_percent , unit_4_score , unit_4_percent , # unit_5_6_score , unit_5_6_percent , unit_7_score , # unit_7_percent , unit_8_score , unit_8_percent , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Use `select` to order columns ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} college_grad_students %>% select(major_code, grad_total, grad_sample_size, everything()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 173 √ó 22 major_code grad_total grad_sample_size major major_category grad_employed 1 5601 9173 200 Construc‚Ä¶ Industrial Ar‚Ä¶ 7098 2 6004 53864 882 Commerci‚Ä¶ Arts 40492 3 6211 24417 437 Hospital‚Ä¶ Business 18368 4 2201 5411 72 Cosmetol‚Ä¶ Industrial Ar‚Ä¶ 3590 5 2001 9109 171 Communic‚Ä¶ Computers & M‚Ä¶ 7512 6 3201 1542 22 Court Re‚Ä¶ Law & Public ‚Ä¶ 1008 7 6206 190996 3738 Marketin‚Ä¶ Business 151570 8 1101 17488 386 Agricult‚Ä¶ Agriculture &‚Ä¶ 13104 9 2101 5611 98 Computer‚Ä¶ Computers & M‚Ä¶ 4716 10 1904 33928 688 Advertis‚Ä¶ Communication‚Ä¶ 28517 # ‚Ñπ 163 more rows # ‚Ñπ 16 more variables: grad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # grad_unemployed , grad_unemployment_rate , grad_p25th , # grad_median , grad_p75th , nongrad_total , # nongrad_employed , nongrad_employed_fulltime_yearround , # nongrad_unemployed , nongrad_unemployment_rate , # nongrad_p25th , nongrad_median , nongrad_p75th , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: . . . `everything()` is a helper verb that includes **all** column names ## `starts_with()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% select(starts_with("test")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 3 test_year test_type test_site 1 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 2 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 3 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 4 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 5 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 6 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 7 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 8 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 9 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN 10 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM YEAR END VIRDEN # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `ends_with()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% select(ends_with("score")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 10 pre_test_score post_test_score unit_1_score unit_2_score unit_3_score 1 43 92 3 4 6 2 46 104 5 5 6 3 39 75 4 4 6 4 35 115 4 4 6 5 46 85 2 5 6 6 35 91 5 5 7 7 40 96 5 5 6 8 39 74 4 5 5 9 40 90 6 4 5 10 45 86 4 5 5 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows # ‚Ñπ 5 more variables: unit_4_score , unit_5_6_score , # unit_7_score , unit_8_score , total_score ``` ::: ::: ## `contains()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% select(contains("test")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 7 test_year test_type test_site pre_test_score pre_test_percent post_test_score 1 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 43 29% 92 2 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 46 31% 104 3 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 39 26% 75 4 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 35 23% 115 5 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 46 31% 85 6 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 35 23% 91 7 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 40 27% 96 8 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 39 26% 74 9 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 40 27% 90 10 06/01/20‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN 45 30% 86 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows # ‚Ñπ 1 more variable: post_test_percent ``` ::: ::: ## `all_of()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vars <- c("pre_test_score", "pre_test_percent", "post_test_score", "post_test_percent") reads %>% select(all_of(vars)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 4 pre_test_score pre_test_percent post_test_score post_test_percent 1 43 29% 92 61% 2 46 31% 104 69% 3 39 26% 75 50% 4 35 23% 115 77% 5 46 31% 85 57% 6 35 23% 91 61% 7 40 27% 96 64% 8 39 26% 74 49% 9 40 27% 90 60% 10 45 30% 86 57% # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `all_of()` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} vars <- c("pre_test_score", "pre_test_percent", "post_test_score", "post_test_percent") mpg %>% select(all_of(vars)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in `select()`: ‚Ñπ In argument: `all_of(vars)`. Caused by error in `all_of()`: ! Can't subset elements that don't exist. ‚úñ Elements `pre_test_score`, `pre_test_percent`, `post_test_score`, and `post_test_percent` don't exist. ``` ::: ::: ## `any_of()` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} vars <- c("pre_test_score", "pre_test_percent", "post_test_score", "post_test_percent") reads %>% select(any_of(vars)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 4 pre_test_score pre_test_percent post_test_score post_test_percent 1 43 29% 92 61% 2 46 31% 104 69% 3 39 26% 75 50% 4 35 23% 115 77% 5 46 31% 85 57% 6 35 23% 91 61% 7 40 27% 96 64% 8 39 26% 74 49% 9 40 27% 90 60% 10 45 30% 86 57% # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `any_of()` ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|4"} vars <- c("pre_test_score", "pre_test_percent", "post_test_score", "post_test_percent") mpg %>% select(any_of(vars)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 234 √ó 0 ``` ::: ::: ## Mix `select` methods and helpers You can mix types and helper functions ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% select(student_id, 1, starts_with("total")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 4 student_id test_year total_score total_percent_correct 1 Virden 1 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 207 41% 2 Virden 2 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 224 45% 3 Virden 3 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 193 39% 4 Virden 4 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 223 45% 5 Virden 5 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 198 40% 6 Virden 6 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 210 42% 7 Virden 7 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 211 42% 8 Virden 8 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 180 36% 9 Virden 9 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 206 41% 10 Virden 10 06/01/2016 12:00:00 AM 206 41% # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Mix `select` methods and helpers You can also use select to rearrange your columns ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% select(student_id, 1, starts_with("total"), everything()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 25 student_id test_year total_score total_percent_correct test_type test_site 1 Virden 1 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 207 41% YEAR END VIRDEN 2 Virden 2 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 224 45% YEAR END VIRDEN 3 Virden 3 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 193 39% YEAR END VIRDEN 4 Virden 4 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 223 45% YEAR END VIRDEN 5 Virden 5 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 198 40% YEAR END VIRDEN 6 Virden 6 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 210 42% YEAR END VIRDEN 7 Virden 7 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 211 42% YEAR END VIRDEN 8 Virden 8 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 180 36% YEAR END VIRDEN 9 Virden 9 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 206 41% YEAR END VIRDEN 10 Virden 10 06/01/2016 ‚Ä¶ 206 41% YEAR END VIRDEN # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows # ‚Ñπ 19 more variables: pre_test_score , pre_test_percent , # post_test_score , post_test_percent , percentage_change , # unit_1_score , unit_1_percent , unit_2_score , # unit_2_percent , unit_3_score , unit_3_percent , # unit_4_score , unit_4_percent , unit_5_6_score , # unit_5_6_percent , unit_7_score , unit_7_percent , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## `relocate()` [relocate(]{style="color:#D55E00"}[.data]{style="color:#56B4E9"}, ... [.before = NULL]{style="color:#009E73"}, [.after = NULL]{style="color:#E69f00"}[)]{style="color:#D55E00"} . . . [.data]{style="color:#56B4E9"} = dataframe/tibble ... = columns to move [.before]{style="color:#009E73"} = variable to move *before* [.after]{style="color:#E69f00"} = variable to move *after* - supplying neither [.before]{style="color:#009E73"} nor [.after]{style="color:#E69f00"} move columns to the left-hand side - specifying both is an error ## `relocate()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% relocate(party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 4 party name start end 1 Republican Eisenhower 1953-01-20 1961-01-20 2 Democratic Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 3 Democratic Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 4 Republican Nixon 1969-01-20 1974-08-09 5 Republican Ford 1974-08-09 1977-01-20 6 Democratic Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 7 Republican Reagan 1981-01-20 1989-01-20 8 Republican Bush 1989-01-20 1993-01-20 9 Democratic Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 10 Republican Bush 2001-01-20 2009-01-20 11 Democratic Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 12 Republican Trump 2017-01-20 2021-01-20 ``` ::: ::: ::: aside moves "party" to far left (default) ::: ## `relocate()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% relocate(party, .after = start) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 4 name start party end 1 Eisenhower 1953-01-20 Republican 1961-01-20 2 Kennedy 1961-01-20 Democratic 1963-11-22 3 Johnson 1963-11-22 Democratic 1969-01-20 4 Nixon 1969-01-20 Republican 1974-08-09 5 Ford 1974-08-09 Republican 1977-01-20 6 Carter 1977-01-20 Democratic 1981-01-20 7 Reagan 1981-01-20 Republican 1989-01-20 8 Bush 1989-01-20 Republican 1993-01-20 9 Clinton 1993-01-20 Democratic 2001-01-20 10 Bush 2001-01-20 Republican 2009-01-20 11 Obama 2009-01-20 Democratic 2017-01-20 12 Trump 2017-01-20 Republican 2021-01-20 ``` ::: ::: ::: aside moves "party" after "start" ::: ## `relocate()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% relocate(end, .before = party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Eisenhower 1953-01-20 1961-01-20 Republican 2 Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 Democratic 3 Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 Democratic 4 Nixon 1969-01-20 1974-08-09 Republican 5 Ford 1974-08-09 1977-01-20 Republican 6 Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 Democratic 7 Reagan 1981-01-20 1989-01-20 Republican 8 Bush 1989-01-20 1993-01-20 Republican 9 Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 Democratic 10 Bush 2001-01-20 2009-01-20 Republican 11 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic 12 Trump 2017-01-20 2021-01-20 Republican ``` ::: ::: ::: aside moves "end" before "party" ::: # `filter()` ## `filter()` [**choose rows**]{style="color:#56B4E9"} that satisfy your condition (`== TRUE`) :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} filter(df, type == "otter", site == "bay") ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations/master/rstats-artwork/dplyr_filter.jpg){fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: aside Illustration by [Allison Horst](https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations/) ::: ## `filter()` {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Complete set of boolean operations - *x* is the left-hand circle - *y* is the right-hand circle - the shaded region show which parts each operator selects + *xor* == *x* or *y* except where they overlap **==** : equal **!** : negates **!=** : NOT equal **&** : and **|** : or ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/01f4b6d39d2be8269740a3ad7946faa79f7243cf/8369a/diagrams/transform-logical.png) ::: ::: ::: :::: ## `filter()` numeric :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% filter(cyl == 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 81 √ó 11 manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 18 29 p comp‚Ä¶ 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manu‚Ä¶ f 21 29 p comp‚Ä¶ 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manu‚Ä¶ f 20 31 p comp‚Ä¶ 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 21 30 p comp‚Ä¶ 5 audi a4 quattro 1.8 1999 4 manu‚Ä¶ 4 18 26 p comp‚Ä¶ 6 audi a4 quattro 1.8 1999 4 auto‚Ä¶ 4 16 25 p comp‚Ä¶ 7 audi a4 quattro 2 2008 4 manu‚Ä¶ 4 20 28 p comp‚Ä¶ 8 audi a4 quattro 2 2008 4 auto‚Ä¶ 4 19 27 p comp‚Ä¶ 9 chevrolet malibu 2.4 1999 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 19 27 r mids‚Ä¶ 10 chevrolet malibu 2.4 2008 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 22 30 r mids‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 71 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% filter(hwy >= 22) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 143 √ó 11 manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 18 29 p comp‚Ä¶ 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manu‚Ä¶ f 21 29 p comp‚Ä¶ 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manu‚Ä¶ f 20 31 p comp‚Ä¶ 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto‚Ä¶ f 21 30 p comp‚Ä¶ 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto‚Ä¶ f 16 26 p comp‚Ä¶ 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manu‚Ä¶ f 18 26 p comp‚Ä¶ 7 audi a4 3.1 2008 6 auto‚Ä¶ f 18 27 p comp‚Ä¶ 8 audi a4 quattro 1.8 1999 4 manu‚Ä¶ 4 18 26 p comp‚Ä¶ 9 audi a4 quattro 1.8 1999 4 auto‚Ä¶ 4 16 25 p comp‚Ä¶ 10 audi a4 quattro 2 2008 4 manu‚Ä¶ 4 20 28 p comp‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 133 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## `filter` for Democrats note the use of `==` NOT `=` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(party == "Democratic") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 Democratic 2 Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 Democratic 3 Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 Democratic 4 Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 Democratic 5 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(party = "Democratic") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in `filter()`: ! We detected a named input. ‚Ñπ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`. ‚Ñπ Did you mean `party == "Democratic"`? ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## `filter` character note the use of `==` NOT `=` ::: {.cell} ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg_ %>% filter(manufacturer == "pontiac") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 5 manufacturer model displ year cyl 1 pontiac grand prix 3.1 1999 6 2 pontiac grand prix 3.8 1999 6 3 pontiac grand prix 3.8 1999 6 4 pontiac grand prix 3.8 2008 6 5 pontiac grand prix 5.3 2008 8 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(party == "Democratic") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Kennedy 1961-01-20 1963-11-22 Democratic 2 Johnson 1963-11-22 1969-01-20 Democratic 3 Carter 1977-01-20 1981-01-20 Democratic 4 Clinton 1993-01-20 2001-01-20 Democratic 5 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Democrats starting after 2000 `,` is equivalent to `&` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(party == "Democratic" & start > "2000-01-01") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(party == "Democratic", start > "2000-01-01") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 √ó 4 name start end party 1 Obama 2009-01-20 2017-01-20 Democratic ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## `filter()` note {.smaller} * The order of operations doesn‚Äôt work like English * Can‚Äôt write: + `filter(presidential, name == "Kennedy" | "Johnson")` * Must be: + `filter(presidential, name == "Kennedy" | name == "Johnson")` ## more `filter()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 25 test_year test_type test_site student_id pre_test_score pre_test_percent 1 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 1 43 29% 2 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 2 46 31% 3 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 3 39 26% 4 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 4 35 23% 5 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 5 46 31% 6 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 6 35 23% 7 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 7 40 27% 8 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 8 39 26% 9 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 9 40 27% 10 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 10 45 30% # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows # ‚Ñπ 19 more variables: post_test_score , post_test_percent , # percentage_change , unit_1_score , unit_1_percent , # unit_2_score , unit_2_percent , unit_3_score , # unit_3_percent , unit_4_score , unit_4_percent , # unit_5_6_score , unit_5_6_percent , unit_7_score , # unit_7_percent , unit_8_score , unit_8_percent , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## more `filter()` Anomaly in the data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} reads %>% count(student_id) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 46 √ó 2 student_id n 1 All Students (Average) 3 2 Jones 1 1 3 Jones 10 1 4 Jones 11 1 5 Jones 12 1 6 Jones 13 1 7 Jones 14 1 8 Jones 15 1 9 Jones 2 1 10 Jones 3 1 # ‚Ñπ 36 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Let's remove these aggregate rows ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|4|5"} students_only <- reads %>% filter(student_id != "All Students (Average)") students_only %>% count(student_id) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 45 √ó 2 student_id n 1 Jones 1 1 2 Jones 10 1 3 Jones 11 1 4 Jones 12 1 5 Jones 13 1 6 Jones 14 1 7 Jones 15 1 8 Jones 2 1 9 Jones 3 1 10 Jones 4 1 # ‚Ñπ 35 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Not equal `!` means **NOT** `!=` means **NOT equal** Note: - If you want values that are NOT `NA`: + `!is.na(variable)` + ~~`variable != NA`~~ ## Chaining `{dplyr}` functions What if we wanted to `select` and `filter` a data set? Select "*name*" and "*party*" of presidents who began their term after 2000 . . . (1) Two step method üòê ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|3"} after_2000 <- filter(presidential, start > as.Date("2000-01-01")) select(after_2000, name, party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 name party 1 Bush Republican 2 Obama Democratic 3 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Chaining `{dplyr}` functions (2) Alternatively, we could wrap `select` around `filter` ‚òπÔ∏è ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(filter(presidential, start > as.Date("2000-01-01")), name, party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 name party 1 Bush Republican 2 Obama Democratic 3 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Chaining `{dplyr}` functions (3) Piping functions üéâ We could use the pipe function to help increase the readability of our code:
`%>%`
Called the "pipe" operator and "piping functions" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} filter(presidential, start > as.Date("2000-01-01")) %>% select(name, party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 name party 1 Bush Republican 2 Obama Democratic 3 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ## Piping functions {.smaller} Even better: * Generally when using the pipe, the first argument is the data set, which gets piped through the corresponding functions * So the code on the prior slide would be: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} presidential %>% filter(start > as.Date("2000-01-01")) %>% select(name, party) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 name party 1 Bush Republican 2 Obama Democratic 3 Trump Republican ``` ::: ::: ::: aside Note the lovely indentations and line breaks to help keep things straight ::: # `mutate()` ## Some new data ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} (prepost <- reads %>% select(student_id, test_site, pre_test_score, post_test_score)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 4 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score 1 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 2 Virden 2 VIRDEN 46 104 3 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 4 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 6 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 7 Virden 7 VIRDEN 40 96 8 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 9 Virden 9 VIRDEN 40 90 10 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `mutate()` **Add** a variable ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} prepost %>% mutate(gain = post_test_score - pre_test_score) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 5 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain 1 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 49 2 Virden 2 VIRDEN 46 104 58 3 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 36 4 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 39 6 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 56 7 Virden 7 VIRDEN 40 96 56 8 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 35 9 Virden 9 VIRDEN 40 90 50 10 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 41 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} names(prepost) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "student_id" "test_site" "pre_test_score" "post_test_score" ``` ::: ::: . . . Why do we not see the new *gain* column? ## `mutate()` **Add** *multiple* variables ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost <- prepost %>% mutate( gain = post_test_score - pre_test_score, sum_tests = post_test_score + pre_test_score ) prepost ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 6 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests 1 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 49 135 2 Virden 2 VIRDEN 46 104 58 150 3 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 36 114 4 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 150 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 39 131 6 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 56 126 7 Virden 7 VIRDEN 40 96 56 136 8 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 35 113 9 Virden 9 VIRDEN 40 90 50 130 10 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 41 131 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `mutate()` **Change** a variable ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost <- prepost %>% mutate(sum_tests = (sum_tests/180) * 100) prepost ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 6 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests 1 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 49 75 2 Virden 2 VIRDEN 46 104 58 83.3 3 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 36 63.3 4 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 83.3 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 39 72.8 6 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 56 70 7 Virden 7 VIRDEN 40 96 56 75.6 8 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 35 62.8 9 Virden 9 VIRDEN 40 90 50 72.2 10 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 41 72.8 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: # `arrange()` ## `arrange()` Order the data - Order by *gain*, ascending [default] ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% arrange(gain) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 6 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests 1 Jones 12 JONES 27 32 5 32.8 2 Westside 6 WESTSIDE 57 82 25 77.2 3 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 35 62.8 4 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 36 63.3 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 39 72.8 6 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 41 72.8 7 Jones 3 JONES 54 95 41 82.8 8 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 49 75 9 Jones 13 JONES 49 98 49 81.7 10 Westside 13 WESTSIDE 45 94 49 77.2 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `arrange()` Order the data - Order by *pre_test_score* and *gain*, ascending ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% arrange(pre_test_score, gain) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 6 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests 1 Jones 11 JONES 24 108 84 73.3 2 Jones 4 JONES 25 99 74 68.9 3 Jones 12 JONES 27 32 5 32.8 4 Virden 12 VIRDEN 31 102 71 73.9 5 Virden 11 VIRDEN 32 91 59 68.3 6 Virden 13 VIRDEN 33 86 53 66.1 7 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 56 70 8 Virden 15 VIRDEN 35 101 66 75.6 9 Jones 9 JONES 35 109 74 80 10 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 83.3 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `arrange()` Order the data - Order by *gain*, `desc`ending ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% arrange(desc(gain)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 6 student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests 1 Jones 11 JONES 24 108 84 73.3 2 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 83.3 3 Jones 4 JONES 25 99 74 68.9 4 Jones 5 JONES 36 110 74 81.1 5 Jones 9 JONES 35 109 74 80 6 Virden 12 VIRDEN 31 102 71 73.9 7 Jones 1 JONES 36 103 67 77.2 8 Virden 15 VIRDEN 35 101 66 75.6 9 Jones 6 JONES 40 106 66 81.1 10 Westside 8 WESTSIDE 43 109 66 84.4 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## `summarize()` {.smaller} `summarize()` or `summarise()` * Here: compute the `mean` and `standard deviation` of the gain scores * What are we looking at? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% summarize(mean_gain = mean(gain, na.rm = TRUE), sd_gain = sd(gain, na.rm = TRUE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 √ó 2 mean_gain sd_gain 1 56.3 13.6 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: aside This is a good start for a descriptive table! ::: # `group_by()` ## :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-gapminder/fig/13-dplyr-fig2.png) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-gapminder/fig/13-dplyr-fig3.png) ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: aside Image from [Software Carpentry](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-gapminder/13-dplyr/) ::: ## `group_by()` Conduct an operation for each level of a grouping factor Here, compute the mean gain for each *test site* ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3"} prepost %>% group_by(test_site) %>% summarize(mean_gain = mean(gain)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 2 test_site mean_gain 1 JONES 59 2 JONES ALL 59 3 VIRDEN 53.8 4 VIRDEN ALL 53 5 WESTSIDE 56.3 6 WESTSIDE ALL 56 ``` ::: ::: ## `group_by()` {.smaller} When you use `group_by()` and `summarize()` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} You will get a row for each unique group ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% group_by(cyl) %>% summarize(max_hwy = max(hwy)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 √ó 2 cyl max_hwy 1 4 44 2 5 29 3 6 29 4 8 26 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} If you have multiple grouping variables, you will get a row for each unique combination of groups ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% group_by(cyl, drv) %>% summarize(max_hwy = max(hwy)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 √ó 3 # Groups: cyl [4] cyl drv max_hwy 1 4 4 28 2 4 f 44 3 5 f 29 4 6 4 25 5 6 f 29 6 6 r 26 7 8 4 23 8 8 f 25 9 8 r 26 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Add summarized column to full data Use `mutate()`! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% group_by(test_site) %>% mutate(mean_gain = mean(gain)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 48 √ó 7 # Groups: test_site [6] student_id test_site pre_test_score post_test_score gain sum_tests mean_gain 1 Virden 1 VIRDEN 43 92 49 75 53.8 2 Virden 2 VIRDEN 46 104 58 83.3 53.8 3 Virden 3 VIRDEN 39 75 36 63.3 53.8 4 Virden 4 VIRDEN 35 115 80 83.3 53.8 5 Virden 5 VIRDEN 46 85 39 72.8 53.8 6 Virden 6 VIRDEN 35 91 56 70 53.8 7 Virden 7 VIRDEN 40 96 56 75.6 53.8 8 Virden 8 VIRDEN 39 74 35 62.8 53.8 9 Virden 9 VIRDEN 40 90 50 72.2 53.8 10 Virden 10 VIRDEN 45 86 41 72.8 53.8 # ‚Ñπ 38 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Retain only summarized columns Use `summarize()`! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} prepost %>% group_by(test_site) %>% summarize(mean_gain = mean(gain)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 2 test_site mean_gain 1 JONES 59 2 JONES ALL 59 3 VIRDEN 53.8 4 VIRDEN ALL 53 5 WESTSIDE 56.3 6 WESTSIDE ALL 56 ``` ::: ::: ## Pipe to `{ggplot}`! ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1,2,3|4|5|6"} prepost %>% group_by(test_site) %>% summarize(mean_gain = mean(gain)) %>% ggplot(aes(test_site, mean_gain)) + geom_col(fill = "cornflowerblue", alpha = .7) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w4_dplyr_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-62-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## ![](./images/kd.gif) ## Summarizing and Plotting - Calculate mean *post_test_score* by test site ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3"} students_only %>% group_by(test_site) %>% summarize(mean = mean(post_test_score)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 2 test_site mean 1 JONES 97.8 2 VIRDEN 92.5 3 WESTSIDE 103. ``` ::: ::: ## Plot it ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|3|4|5|6|7"} theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 18)) students_only %>% group_by(test_site) %>% summarize(mean = mean(post_test_score)) %>% ggplot(aes(test_site, mean)) + geom_col(alpha = 0.8) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w4_dplyr_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-64-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: # A couple more `recode()` and `rename()` ## Recode with `ifelse()` Recoding into dichotomous variable with `ifelse()` `ifelse(`test, yes, no`)` *or* `ifelse(`logical statement, do this `if` TRUE, `else` do this`)` ## Recode with `ifelse()` Recoding into dichotomous variable with `ifelse()` **Remember to pair with `mutate()`!** ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} students_only %>% mutate(New_test_site = ifelse(test_site == "JONES", "district 1", "district 2")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 45 √ó 26 test_year test_type test_site student_id pre_test_score pre_test_percent 1 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 1 43 29% 2 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 2 46 31% 3 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 3 39 26% 4 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 4 35 23% 5 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 5 46 31% 6 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 6 35 23% 7 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 7 40 27% 8 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 8 39 26% 9 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 9 40 27% 10 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END VIRDEN Virden 10 45 30% # ‚Ñπ 35 more rows # ‚Ñπ 20 more variables: post_test_score , post_test_percent , # percentage_change , unit_1_score , unit_1_percent , # unit_2_score , unit_2_percent , unit_3_score , # unit_3_percent , unit_4_score , unit_4_percent , # unit_5_6_score , unit_5_6_percent , unit_7_score , # unit_7_percent , unit_8_score , unit_8_percent , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Recode with `recode()` Recoding into multinomial variable ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} recode(variable, old_category_1 = "new_category_1", old_category_2 = "new_category_2", old_category_3 = "new_category_3", ... ) ``` ::: ## Recode with `recode()` Recoding into multinomial variable **Remember to pair with `mutate()`** ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code} students_only %>% mutate(test_site = recode(test_site, JONES = "Jones Middle", VIRDEN = "Virden Elementary", WESTSIDE = "Westside High") ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 45 √ó 25 test_year test_type test_site student_id pre_test_score pre_test_percent 1 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 1 43 29% 2 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 2 46 31% 3 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 3 39 26% 4 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 4 35 23% 5 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 5 46 31% 6 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 6 35 23% 7 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 7 40 27% 8 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 8 39 26% 9 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 9 40 27% 10 06/01/2016 12‚Ä¶ YEAR END Virden E‚Ä¶ Virden 10 45 30% # ‚Ñπ 35 more rows # ‚Ñπ 19 more variables: post_test_score , post_test_percent , # percentage_change , unit_1_score , unit_1_percent , # unit_2_score , unit_2_percent , unit_3_score , # unit_3_percent , unit_4_score , unit_4_percent , # unit_5_6_score , unit_5_6_percent , unit_7_score , # unit_7_percent , unit_8_score , unit_8_percent , ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Recode with `recode()` Remember to use backticks for special characters ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mtcars %>% mutate(cyl_str = recode(cyl, `4` = "cylinders4", `6` = "cylinders6", `8` = "cylinders8")) ``` ::: ## Recode with `case_when()` {.smaller} Recoding across several variables, or if you find yourself using nested `ifelse()` statements **Remember to pair with `mutate()`** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|6|7|8|9"} library(palmerpenguins) penguins %>% mutate(species_big = case_when( body_mass_g > 4500 & species == "Adelie" ~ "adelie_big", body_mass_g > 4600 & species == "Chinstrap" ~ "chinstrap_big", body_mass_g > 6000 & species == "Gentoo" ~ "gentoo_big", .default = "other" )) ``` ::: . . . `.default` equivalent to `all else` ## `rename()` {.smaller} `rename(new_name = old_name)` **NOT paired with `mutate()`** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% rename( home = island, bill_length = bill_length_mm ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 √ó 8 species home bill_length bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g sex 1 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 39.1 18.7 181 3750 male 2 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 39.5 17.4 186 3800 fema‚Ä¶ 3 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 40.3 18 195 3250 fema‚Ä¶ 4 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 36.7 19.3 193 3450 fema‚Ä¶ 6 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 39.3 20.6 190 3650 male 7 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 38.9 17.8 181 3625 fema‚Ä¶ 8 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 39.2 19.6 195 4675 male 9 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 34.1 18.1 193 3475 10 Adelie Torger‚Ä¶ 42 20.2 190 4250 # ‚Ñπ 334 more rows # ‚Ñπ 1 more variable: year ``` ::: ::: ## rename with `select()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins %>% select(species, home = island, bill_length = bill_length_mm, year) #<< ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 √ó 4 species home bill_length year 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 2007 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 2007 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 2007 4 Adelie Torgersen NA 2007 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 2007 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 2007 7 Adelie Torgersen 38.9 2007 8 Adelie Torgersen 39.2 2007 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 2007 10 Adelie Torgersen 42 2007 # ‚Ñπ 334 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Final notes on `{dplyr}` * We could spend weeks on this * We'll be using it all term long * Verbs can help you gain fluency * There are also conditional and all-inclusive versions of `mutate`, `select`, and `summarize` + [`across()`](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/across.html) # Next time ## Before next class {.smaller} - Final Project + [Final Project: Outline]{style="color:#FF0000"} - Reading + [Bryan (2017)](https://peerj.com/preprints/3159v2/) - Activities + Download [GitKraken](https://www.gitkraken.com/) + Watch [What is a Git repository?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-4WltCTVms&list=PLe6EXFvnTV7-_41SpakZoTIYCgX4aMTdU&index=3) + Watch [What is a remote repository?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lb4yvfrX_7I&list=PLe6EXFvnTV7-_41SpakZoTIYCgX4aMTdU&index=3) - Homework + Homework 4

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
